We are very close to finish caseI, but the end of the proof may be quite painful to formalize, so let me resume the situation to see if anyone has any idea to simplify the proof. This is purely a Lean question, mathematically there is almost nothing to prove.

The situation is the following: we have a prime p such that p ‚â• 5, a b c : ‚Ñ§ such that ¬¨ p ‚à£ a * b * c, ¬¨a ‚â° b [ZMOD p] and is_unit (({a, b, c} : finset ‚Ñ§).gcd id). We suppose that a * b * c ‚â† 0 and we want to prove a ^ p + b ^ p ‚â† c ^ p. The precise Lean statement is

theorem caseI_easier {a b c : ‚Ñ§} (hpri : p.prime)
  (hreg : is_regular_number p hpri.pos) (hp5 : 5 ‚â§ p) (hprod : a * b * c ‚â† 0)
  (hgcd : is_unit (({a, b, c} : finset ‚Ñ§).gcd id))
  (hab : ¬¨a ‚â° b [ZMOD p]) (caseI : ¬¨ ‚Üëp ‚à£ a * b * c) : a ^ p + b ^ p ‚â† c ^ p :=

(we already know this implies caseI).

Now, the math proof is the following: let Œ∂\zetaŒ∂ be a primitive ppp-th root of unity and let KKK be Q(Œ∂)\mathbb{Q}(Œ∂)Q(Œ∂), with ring of integers RRR. Using the regularity assumption, we can find u‚ààR‚àóu ‚àà R^\astu‚ààR‚àó and Œ±‚ààR\alpha \in RŒ±‚ààR such that x+yŒ∂=uŒ±x+y\zeta=u \alphax+yŒ∂=uŒ±. This is also formalized (modulo a sorried statement, but this is irrelevant) as

theorem is_principal {a b c : ‚Ñ§} {Œ∂ : R} (hreg : is_regular_number p hpri.pos) (hp5 : 5 ‚â§ p)
  (hgcd : is_unit (({a, b, c} : finset ‚Ñ§).gcd id)) (caseI : ¬¨ ‚Üëp ‚à£ a * b * c)
  (H : a ^ p + b ^ p = c ^ p) (hŒ∂ : is_primitive_root Œ∂ p) :
  ‚àÉ (u : RÀ£) (Œ± : R), ‚Üëu * (Œ± ^ p) = ‚Üëa + Œ∂ * ‚Üëb

Now, this implies that there is k‚ààZk \in \mathbb{Z}k‚ààZ such that a+bŒ∂‚àíŒ∂2ka‚àíŒ∂2k‚àí1b‚â°0‚Äämod‚Ääpa + b\zeta -\zeta^{2k}a -\zeta^{2k-1}b \equiv 0 \bmod{p}a+bŒ∂‚àíŒ∂2ka‚àíŒ∂2k‚àí1b‚â°0modp. The end of the proof is the following: If 1,Œ∂,Œ∂2k,Œ∂2k‚àí11,\zeta,\zeta^{2k},\zeta^{2k-1}1,Œ∂,Œ∂2k,Œ∂2k‚àí1 are distinct, then this Lemma says that (since p‚â•5p \geq 5p‚â•5) ppp divides a,ba,ba,b, contrary to our assumption. So they cannot be distinct, but checking each case leads to a contradiction, therefore there cannot be any such solutions.

I've formalized the Lemma as follows:

lemma dvd_coeff_cycl_integer [hp : fact (p : ‚Ñï).prime] {Œ∂ : L} (hŒ∂ : is_primitive_root Œ∂ p)
  {f : fin p ‚Üí ‚Ñ§} {i : fin p} (hf : f i = 0) {m : ‚Ñ§}
  (hdiv : ‚Üëm ‚à£ ‚àë j, f j ‚Ä¢ (‚ü®Œ∂, hŒ∂.is_integral p.pos‚ü© : ùìû L) ^ (j : ‚Ñï)) : ‚àÄ j, m ‚à£ f j

And the existence of kkk as follows:

lemma exists_int_sum_eq_zero (hpodd : p ‚â† 2) [hp : fact(p : ‚Ñï).prime] {x y i : ‚Ñ§} {u : (ùìû K)À£}
  {Œ± : ùìû K} (h : (x : ùìû K) + y * (hŒ∂.unit' ^ i : (ùìû K)À£) = u * Œ± ^ (p : ‚Ñï)) :
  ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, (x : ùìû K) + y * (hŒ∂.unit' ^ i : (ùìû K)À£) - (hŒ∂.unit' ^ (2 * k) : (ùìû K)À£) *
    (x + y * (hŒ∂.unit' ^ -i : (ùìû K)À£)) ‚àà ideal.span ({p} : set (ùìû K))

here hŒ∂.unit' is the primitive root as a unit of the ring of integers (this is necessary to take integer-valued powers).

There are several problem to glue these two statements. First of all, in exists_int_sum_eq_zero the exponents are integers, not elements of fin p (it is necessary to go through fin p at some moment, since the proof of dvd_coeff_cycl_integer uses the power basis given by Œ∂\zetaŒ∂, that is indexed over fin p). Of course we can modify exists_int_sum_eq_zero to use fin p exponents, but and this is what I started doing.

Then one has to build f to apply dvd_coeff_cycl_integer, and this is going to be a pain I think. Then we one has to consider the remaining cases (when the 1,Œ∂,Œ∂2k,Œ∂2k‚àí11,\zeta,\zeta^{2k},\zeta^{2k-1}1,Œ∂,Œ∂2k,Œ∂2k‚àí1 are not all distinct), and also this will be a pain I am afraid.

My current idea is to avoid dvd_coeff_cycl_integer completely, at least in the form it is stated now and proving that p ‚à£ a and p ‚à£ b (leading to a contradiction) by hand, reusing the proof of dvd_coeff_cycl_integer`.

In practice, it shouldn't be too hard to prove that p divides the coefficient of 1 in the expansion of a+bŒ∂‚àíŒ∂2ka‚àíŒ∂2k‚àí1ba + b\zeta -\zeta^{2k}a -\zeta^{2k-1}ba+bŒ∂‚àíŒ∂2ka‚àíŒ∂2k‚àí1b. This coefficients is a unless \zeta^{2k} = 1 or \zeta^{2k-1}= 1 (that is impossible, and this should be proved before). Then proceed similarly for b. There will still be four preliminary thing to prove, but at least we can avoid building f.
Sorry for the long message, but if anyone has any better idea I am very happy to listen to any suggestion.

I thought about this a bit. Can't you define f to be the sum of "if x=0 then a else if x=1 then b else 0" and "if x=2k then -a else if x=2k-1 then -b else 0" and then split on whether 2k=0?
Yes, that's the idea. I also thought about using docs#set.indicator. I have to try to see how annoying is to connect the sum over fin p to the actual sum of four elements and similar things.
This approach is definitely better, even if not completely painless. See here for a precise question.
Using @Floris van Doorn's suggestion everything it's much much better!

I've finished the proof of the main statement of caseI.

This means that the only sorry left is flt_ideals_coprime. @Chris Birkbeck what is the situation with this lemma? Do you think we're close to it?
Well, it seems we are very close. I am working on the sorry in src/number_theory/cyclotomic/cycl_rat.lean

We were indeed really close.

theorem caseI {a b c : ‚Ñ§} {p : ‚Ñï} (hpri : p.prime) (hreg : is_regular_number p hpri.pos)
  (hodd : p ‚â† 2) (caseI : ¬¨ ‚Üëp ‚à£ a * b * c) : a ^ p + b ^ p ‚â† c ^ p :=
flt_regular.caseI.may_assume (Œª x y z p‚ÇÅ Hpri Hreg HP5 Hunit Hxy HI,
    caseI_easier Hpri Hreg HP5 Hunit Hxy HI) hpri hreg hodd caseI

#print axioms caseI --propext quot.sound classical.choice

It's probably a good idea to do some cleanup and reorganize certain files before starting thinking about caseII. Also, quite a lot of stuff is more or less suitable to be PRed, and I think it's better to do it sooner than later.
For example I started using (hpri: p.prime) instead of fact for some reason, but fact is surely better.

Yes, the blueprint is updated, and also the dependency graph is (at least for case 1, for case 2 it's still just a very preliminary draft).

hreg : is_regular_number p hpri.pos -- you didn't ever define is_regular_prime p? It would read much better!

The statement is not optimized at all. As I said we need to improve a lot of stuff. The fact that p is prime should be a fact instance, so it should disappear, it's there because I was lazy. But I can change is_regular_prime quickly, let me do it.

Now the statement is

theorem caseI {a b c : ‚Ñ§} {p : ‚Ñï} [fact p.prime] (hreg : is_regular_prime p)
  (hodd : p ‚â† 2) (caseI : ¬¨ ‚Üëp ‚à£ a * b * c) : a ^ p + b ^ p ‚â† c ^ p :=
flt_regular.caseI.may_assume (Œª x y z p‚ÇÅ Hpri Hreg Hp5 Hunit Hxy HI H,
  by exactI caseI_easier p‚ÇÅ Hreg Hp5 Hunit Hxy HI H) hreg hodd caseI
